ygData.subject: Re: [archive-crawler] ServerCache lookup stuck
ygData.msgSnippet: Also for reference and possible attempts at crafting a proper stress test: how many CPUs/cores(or virtual-cores) are on your machine? - Gordon

Also for reference and possible attempts at crafting a proper stress 
test: how many CPUs/cores(or virtual-cores) are on your machine?

- Gordon

igor@... wrote:
> Hi Gordon,
> 
> 1) PoolThread-0 is a kill-thread-via-gui:
> 
> "PoolThread-0" prio=10 tid=0x0a1e1400 nid=0xa1b waiting for monitor entry
> [0x8d5fe000..0x8d5ff130]
>    java.lang.Thread.State: BLOCKED (on object monitor)
>         at
> org.archive.util.CachedBdbMap$SoftEntry.getPhantom(CachedBdbMap.java:1625)
>         - waiting to lock <0x97f40ad8> (a
> org.archive.util.CachedBdbMap$SoftEntry)
>         at
> org.archive.util.CachedBdbMap$SoftEntry.isCleared(CachedBdbMap.java:1632)
>         at
> org.archive.util.CachedBdbMap$SoftEntry.awaitExpunge(CachedBdbMap.java:1711)
>         at org.archive.util.CachedBdbMap.isExpunged(CachedBdbMap.java:500)
>         at org.archive.util.CachedBdbMap._getMem(CachedBdbMap.java:698)
>         at org.archive.util.CachedBdbMap.get(CachedBdbMap.java:627)
>         at
> org.archive.crawler.datamodel.ServerCache.getServerFor(ServerCache.java:99)
>         at
> org.archive.crawler.datamodel.ServerCache.getServerFor(ServerCache.java:124)
>         at
> org.archive.crawler.frontier.AbstractFrontier.tally(AbstractFrontier.java:428)
>         at
> org.archive.crawler.frontier.AbstractFrontier.doJournalFinishedFailure(AbstractFrontier.java:465)
>         at
> org.archive.crawler.frontier.WorkQueueFrontier.finished(WorkQueueFrontier.java:918)
>         at org.archive.crawler.framework.ToeThread.kill(ToeThread.java:411)
>         - locked <0x961941f8> (a org.archive.crawler.framework.ToeThread)
>         at org.archive.crawler.framework.ToePool.killThread(ToePool.java:158)
>         at
> org.archive.crawler.framework.CrawlController.killThread(CrawlController.java:1691)
>         at org.archive.crawler.admin.CrawlJob.killThread(CrawlJob.java:968)
>         at
> org.archive.crawler.jspc.admin.reports.threads_jsp._jspService(Unknown
> Source)
>         at
> org.apache.jasper.runtime.HttpJspBase.service(HttpJspBase.java:137)
>         at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service(HttpServlet.java:853)
>         at
> org.mortbay.jetty.servlet.ServletHolder.handle(ServletHolder.java:358)
>         at
> org.mortbay.jetty.servlet.WebApplicationHandler$Chain.doFilter(WebApplicationHandler.java:342)
>         at
> org.archive.crawler.admin.ui.RootFilter.doFilter(RootFilter.java:67)
>         at
> org.mortbay.jetty.servlet.WebApplicationHandler$Chain.doFilter(WebApplicationHandler.java:334)
>         at
> org.mortbay.jetty.servlet.WebApplicationHandler.dispatch(WebApplicationHandler.java:286)
>         at
> org.mortbay.jetty.servlet.ServletHandler.handle(ServletHandler.java:567)
>         at org.mortbay.http.HttpContext.handle(HttpContext.java:1807)
>         at
> org.mortbay.jetty.servlet.WebApplicationContext.handle(WebApplicationContext.java:525)
>         at org.mortbay.http.HttpContext.handle(HttpContext.java:1757)
>         at org.mortbay.http.HttpServer.service(HttpServer.java:879)
>         at org.mortbay.http.HttpConnection.service(HttpConnection.java:789)
>         at
> org.mortbay.http.HttpConnection.handleNext(HttpConnection.java:960)
>         at org.mortbay.http.HttpConnection.handle(HttpConnection.java:806)
>         at
> org.mortbay.http.SocketListener.handleConnection(SocketListener.java:218)
>         at org.mortbay.util.ThreadedServer.handle(ThreadedServer.java:300)
>         at org.mortbay.util.ThreadPool$PoolThread.run(ThreadPool.java:511)
> 
> 
> 2)
>> So if I understand properly: other threads are still proceeding OK, it's
>> just this one host that's not making any progress, because any thread
>> that tries to get an associated CrawlServer (for any reason)
> 
> That is correct.
> 
> 3) dumpExtraStats().
> Here are three consecutive dumps.
> 
> 2009-09-17 18:33:21.822 INFO thread-97
> org.archive.util.CachedBdbMap.dumpExtraStats() DB name:servers,  Cache
> Hit: 99%, Not in map: 79937, Total number of gets: 14330000  1=NullPhantom
>  6=TransientCond  901870921=AwaitExpunge  0=NullValue  0=NotInMap 
> 0=AwaitTimeout  422830=SwapIn  85379=diskHit  14164684=cacheHit 
> 14330000=countOfGets  0=SwapInRetry  887040=DiskPut  0=Remove1Used 
> 0=Remove2Used  0=ReplaceUsed  0=PutUsed  75196=PutIfUsed  0=SyncUsed 
> 79887=diskMapSize  452=memMap.size
> 
> 2009-09-17 18:34:24.189 INFO thread-23
> org.archive.util.CachedBdbMap.dumpExtraStats() DB name:hosts,  Cache Hit:
> 99%, Not in map: 79478, Total number of gets: 14200000  1=NullPhantom 
> 1=TransientCond  0=AwaitExpunge  0=NullValue  0=NotInMap  0=AwaitTimeout 
> 422840=SwapIn  88927=diskHit  14031595=cacheHit  14200000=countOfGets 
> 0=SwapInRetry  888044=DiskPut  0=Remove1Used  0=Remove2Used  0=ReplaceUsed
>  0=PutUsed  74742=PutIfUsed  0=SyncUsed  79417=diskMapSize 
> 274=memMap.size
> 
> 2009-09-17 18:37:07.468 INFO thread-60
> org.archive.util.CachedBdbMap.dumpExtraStats() DB name:servers,  Cache
> Hit: 99%, Not in map: 79986, Total number of gets: 14340000  1=NullPhantom
>  6=TransientCond  1101700501=AwaitExpunge  0=NullVal
> ue  0=NotInMap  0=AwaitTimeout  423101=SwapIn  85433=diskHit 
> 14174581=cacheHit  14340000=countOfGets  0=SwapInRetry  888044=DiskPut 
> 0=Remove1Used  0=Remove2Used  0=ReplaceUsed  0=PutUsed  75245=PutIfUsed 
> 0=SyncUsed  79936=diskMapSize
>  377=memMap.size
> 
> 
> 4)
>> TT#9 was showing same symptom, but different URI/host-in-progress?
> 
> No, that was a typo. It is tt#19 not tt#9. Sorry for the confusion.
> 
> 5)  I will wait another day before trying to manually remove the stuck
> memMap entry.
> 
> Thanks Gordon.
> i.
> 
> 
>> igor@... wrote:
>>>> Still investigating, but thoughts so far:
>>>>
>>>> A notable thing about the "ToeThread #19" dumps is that they are
>>>> usually
>>>> BLOCKED waiting for the monitor on a specific CachedBdbMap$SoftEntry
>>>> instance (<0x97f40ad8>, corresponding to the one server of interest to
>>>> the URI-in-progress). That means some other thread holds it. But
>>>> occasionally, tt#19 holds that lock.
>>> I attached a file with more info.
>>>
>>>> This alternation suggests the other thread or threads are contributors
>>>> to the problem state. You mentioned these might be in the middle of a
>>>> JMX URI import; can you share some of those stacks, too? (Indeed, any
>>>> stack with a reference to <0x97f40ad8> from the same all-threads-dump.)
>>> There are 4 additional threads that are stuck in the same loop: 3 JMX
>>> import URIs and one *gui-kill-and-replace-thread* threads.
>> Can you send one deeper sample of this stack (the "PoolThread-0" I
>> think) -- I'm curious how it got entangled.
>>
>>> Initially there were only two stuck threads, tt#19 and one JMX import
>>> URI
>>> thread. The URI import process is sequential, one url at time, across
>>> all
>>> TLDs. Heritrix instance does not discover URLs itself at all.
>>>
>>> I end up with two more stuck JMX import URI threads because I restarted
>>> the URI import process twice with incorrect filter that drops urls from
>>> the *problematic* site/source-server.
>> So if I understand properly: other threads are still proceeding OK, it's
>> just this one host that's not making any progress, because any thread
>> that tries to get an associated CrawlServer (for any reason)
>>
>>> I also tried to kill tt#9 via GUI but that did not work. Thus, another
>>> stuck thread.
> 
> 
>> The info below is useful too.
>>
>> Current best guess: it appears that the 'expunge' (clearing memMap
>> entry) of a GC'd item only occurs if the keys identity-match on line
>> 1474 of CachedBdbMap. I don't know why they wouldn't match -- must be
>> some other synchronization problem -- but if they don't, there seems no
>> way that key could ever be removed from the map. The necessary exit
>> condition for all the loops is that the key is removed as expected --
>> explaining the thread trap.
>>
>> I think this theory of the loop (if not the original cause) could be
>> confirmed if you could connect to the JVM via JConsole and set the
>> logging level of org.archive.util.CachedBdbMap logger to INFO (at least
>> briefly). There should then be a flurry of output from
>> CachedBdbMap.dumpExtraStats(), and the "NotInMap" value reported as
>> nonzero (and probably increasing rapidly with each loop). Other numbers
>> there might be interesting too.
>>
>> Can you try that?
> 
>> I think manually removing the stuck memMap entry, for example via a
>> one-time BeanshellProcessor script, may release the threads -- though of
>> course the problem could recur because we still don't know how the bad
>> state was initially triggered.
>>
>> It'd be a bit of delicate error-prone surgery on the running process,
>> but the rough approach might be:
>>
>> - pause
>> - add a new BeanshellProcessor
>>    - give it a script somewhat like (untested)...
>>
>> ===
>> run(curi) {
>>    if(curi.getCrawlURIString().equals(
>>         "http://example.com/ONE_TIME_FAKE_TRIGGER_URI")) {
>>      setAccessibility(true);
>>      controller.serverCache.servers.memMap.remove(
>>         "newyork.craigslist.org");
>>    }
>> }
>> ===
>>
>> - add the trigger URI that will pass scoping
>> - unpause
>> - hope for the best & check if it worked
>> - pause and remove BeanshellProcessor until next time problem repeats
>>
>> I've made an issue to track down the underlying trigger bug, see:
>>
>>    https://webarchive.jira.com/browse/HER-1677
>>
>> - Gordon @ IA
>>
>>>> Also, is the reported CPU usage negligible, pegged-near-100%, or
>>>> somewhere in between?
>>> The java process uses about 50% of all cores and that is pretty much
>>> constant even when the crawler instance is paused. There is a constant
>>> JMX
>>> import URI activity, but that is single threaded and I cannot image it
>>> being CPU intensive.
>>>
>>>> Is there a chance the JMX threads are adding many URIs from this same
>>>> source server, and are making very very slow contended progress? (A
>>>> frontier report might show the count of URIs on the corresponding queue
>>>> growing, and maybe even 'lsof -o' would show any read-position progress
>>>> in the source files for the JMX operation, confirming some progress.)
>>>> It
>>>> would be good to know if this is a true endless-hysteresis/loop or just
>>>> pathological slowness under a certain kind of contention.
>>> No, that is not the case.
>>>
>>>> What does the heap usage look like? (The behavior of CachedBdbMap is
>>>> intentionally GC-sensitive; operation under low-memory conditions,
>>>> where
>>>> something is GC'd as soon as it's created, could be part of the problem
>>>> cycle. But that's less likely a factor to consider if there's plenty of
>>>> heap free space.)
>>> It is using only a half of the max heap value.
>>>
>>>> Are you hoping to kick this crawl back into working state (which might
>>>> be possible with enough trickery once we understand the problem), or
>>>> just keeping it around for debugging?
>>> I will like to have it in a working state sooner or later either by
>>> restart or some other trickery. But for now it is still up and running.
>>>
>>> Thanks Gordon.
>>> i.
>>>
>>>
>>>> - Gordon @ IA
>>>>
>>>> igor@... wrote:
>>>>> Hi Gordon,
>>>>>
>>>>> Thanks for looking into it. See comments below.
>>>>>
>>>>>> The CachedBdbMap somewhat recently (since last official release)
>>>>>> underwent some major refactoring to improve concurrency. The test
>>>>>> coverage is reasonable and the code has been through some volume
>>>>>> tests
>>>>>> without showing problems, but this might be a new bug triggered by
>>>>>> that
>>>>>> code.
>>>>>> If you pause the crawl, I presume only that one thread remains
>>>>>> active.
>>>>>> Is that right?
>>>>> Only one toe thread, that is right.
>>>>>
>>>>>> Is the CPU busy with only that thread active? I'm still considering
>>>>>> the
>>>>>> other stacks you forwarded in a subsequent message; can you collect
>>>>>> even
>>>>>> more samples to get a sense of which branches are always being taken
>>>>>> in
>>>>>> the relevant methods?
>>>>> There is more than one thread active given that there is JMX
>>>>> activities
>>>>> even when the crawl is paused.
>>>>>
>>>>> There are at least two more JMX threads (trying to import an URI) that
>>>>> are
>>>>> stuck in the same loop as the toe thread.
>>>>>
>>>>> I attached a file with 100 quick thread dumps related to toe thread
>>>>> #19.
>>>>>
>>>>>> The CachedBdbMap depends on some some garbage-collection-related
>>>>>> trickery that might not be reliable in all JVMs. Can you say what
>>>>>> JVM/host OS you're using?
>>>>> Sun's 1.6 (1.6.0_10-b33) and CentOS (CentOS release 5.3 (Final)).
>>>>>
>>>>> i.
>>>>>
